question: Question_11
statement:
Let \emph{M} be the set

\begin{align*}M = \{ x \in \mathbb{Q} \mid x^2 < 5 \}\end{align*} Find, with proof,
inf(\emph{M}).
sols:
The condition

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
x^2 < 5\end{align*} is equivalent to the conditions

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
- \sqrt{5} < x < \sqrt{5}\end{align*}

This means, we can rewrite the set \emph{M} as being

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
M = \mathbb{Q} \cap (-\sqrt{5},\sqrt{5})\end{align*}

The infimum of a set being the largest real number that is smaller or
equal to all the numbers of the set, it seems to be a good idea to think
that - is a good candidate for the infimum of the set \emph{M}.

Since -Â~is clearly smaller than all the numbers of the set \emph{M}, we
only need to show that it is the largest real number with that property.

Assume that there is a number \emph{m} with that property as well, that
is strictly larger than -, that is

\begin{align*}m \leq x \quad\text{for all } x \in M \quad\text{and}\quad m > -\sqrt{5}\end{align*}
We'll simply show that such a \emph{m} cannot exist and hence - is the
infimum of the set \emph{M}.

Indeed, if \emph{m} is strictly larger than - than it means that the
interval

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
(-\sqrt{5} , m)\end{align*} is not empty. Since non-empty interval of real numbers
contain infinitely many numbers, we can find two distinct numbers in
that interval $x_1$ and $x_2$, that is

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
-\sqrt{5} < x_1 < x_2 < m\end{align*}

Now a property of the rational numbers is that you can always find a
rational number between any two distinct real numbers. That means there
must exist a rational number \emph{q} between $x_1$ and $x_2$, so we
have

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
-\sqrt{5} < x_1 < q < x_2 < m < \sqrt{5}\end{align*} but in particular that means
that \emph{q} is in the interval (-,) and since it is rational, \emph{q}
is an element of the set \emph{M}. But by construction, \emph{q}
\textless{} \emph{m} which contradicts the assumption that \emph{m}
could be a lower bound of the set \emph{M}. This means that such a
number \emph{m} cannot exist and hence the infimum of the set \emph{M}
has to be -.
hints:
Recall that inf(\emph{M}) denotes the
\href{http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infimum}{\emph{infimum}} of the set
\emph{M}, that is the largest real number that is smaller than any
element of the set \emph{M}.
